messageBody:
On 30/11/05, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> Why work on it if the testing framework can do it for you?
>
> Without dependent methods: "10 FAILURES".
>
> With dependent methods: "1 FAILURE, 9 SKIPS".
>
> I know which result I prefer :-)

They both say the same thing to me: I've got something that, if it is
broken, affects lots of tests. That's a design problem to work on,
because it means I've got a lot of coupling (environmental issues
aside).

Personally, I think the 10 failures motivates me to fix the coupling
issue more, but that's personal taste.

Of course, the more likely situation, even with TestNG, is that you'll
have "10 FAILURES" because you didn't think to put the dependency
annotation on because it wasn't immediately obvious that the tests
should be dependent, and for some reason the framework didn't
automatically determine that for you. I'd be willing to lay serious
money on a bet that, for most users of TestNG, that the dependency
annotation goes on _after_ a test failure, not before.
